title: What is the state of the art for rust and dependencies managed with cargo?
body:
[edit: update bat package to use sha256]
[edit2: better cargo invocation in example]

I have a small handful of tools that I'd like to add that are written in rust, e.g. bat:

```python
 from spack import *


 class Bat(Package):
     """A cat(1) clone with wings."""

     homepage = "https://github.com/sharkdp/bat"
     url      = "https://github.com/sharkdp/bat/archive/v0.10.0.tar.gz"

     version('0.10.0', sha256='54dd396e8f20d44c6032a32339f45eab46a69b6134e74a704f8d4a27c18ddc3e')

     depends_on('rust')

     def install(self, spec, prefix):
         cargo = which('cargo')
         cargo('install', '--root', prefix, '--path', '.')
```

Looking at it's cargo.lock file, it appears to have about 214 recursive dependencies.  With the simple recipe above, cargo grabs them at run time and builds them in `~/.cargo`.

That's not very Spack-ish.   Or, given that the `cargo.lock` file includes signatures (sha256?), perhaps grabbing them at run time is sufficiently reliable to not require wheel re-inventing?  The resulting binary seems to be sufficiently self-contained:

```consolesession
$ ldd /home/ghartzell/spack/opt/spack/linux-centos7-x86_64/gcc-8.2.0/bat-0.10.0-xldouz3jymfgh7whohqgfxhvkebnejgf/bin/bat
        linux-vdso.so.1 =>  (0x00007ffeb51ad000)
        libz.so.1 => /home/ghartzell/spack/opt/spack/linux-centos7-x86_64/gcc-8.2.0/zlib-1.2.11-6wdekzyadff6repdb5bxinnzizvnn35t/lib/libz.so.1 (0x00007f5af929a000)
        libc.so.6 => /lib64/libc.so.6 (0x00007f5af8ecd000)
        /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f5af9b99000)
        libdl.so.2 => /lib64/libdl.so.2 (0x00007f5af8cc9000)
        libpthread.so.0 => /lib64/libpthread.so.0 (0x00007f5af8aad000)
        libgcc_s.so.1 => /home/ghartzell/spack/opt/spack/linux-centos7-x86_64/gcc-4.8.5/gcc-8.2.0-uc6sbumioobdbkw4rwfyn2givi4nyvwq/lib64/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007f5af8895000)
        libm.so.6 => /lib64/libm.so.6 (0x00007f5af8593000)
$
```

Is anyone working on rust tooling?  Seems like "someone" could write a tool automated some of the bits if we're not content relying on cargo.
